text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food
whooshes comm live muhammara that's
right this amazing roasted pepper and
walnut spread may be the most delicious
thing you're currently not eating so I'm
very excited to show you how to put this
together and we actually have our recent
Facebook live to thank for that since it
was during that someone requested we do
Lebanese food and this was their
specific food wish although having said
that this is actually a Syrian invention
but extremely popular in Lebanon as it
is throughout the Middle East and once
you taste this you'll fully understand
why and we'll get started by prepping
one of the three main ingredients and
that's going to be our walnuts there
we're gonna wanna toast before we use
and my favorite way to do this is in a
skillet over medium heat with a little
bit of olive oil and what we'll do is
cook those for about five minutes or so
stirring and tossing them quite often
until they're very lightly toasted and I
should mention that this is
traditionally done in the oven but in my
experience it's really hard to catch him
at that perfect moment of toastiness
plus it's a proven scientific fact that
over 50% of nuts put in the oven
actually burn in fact if we have any
prep cooks in the audience they're
totally nodding right now for whatever
reason people always forget the nuts and
they turn black and you have to start
over so what we're gonna do is simply
toast those in a pan for about five
minutes until basically they smell and
taste like toasted walnuts which really
is the best way to check since they're
not going to look that much different
than when you start okay so we don't
want to rely on our eyes too much here
when they start to smell toasted you can
test one and all we're going for is a
very lightly roasted flavor okay don't
go too far and what we'll do as soon as
we reach that point it's quickly
transfer those onto a plate to cool and
then we're basically gonna repeat the
exact same process with some breadcrumbs
which if you're making this the right
way you're actually using stale flat
bread but I actually had a little bit of
bread crumb to use up so that's what I'm
going with here but obviously and as
usual
these kinds of decisions are up to you
so really any kind of dry bread crumb
fine or coarse is going to work here and
all we're gonna do is toast that in
olive oil over medium heat for a few
minutes until it turns a nice light
golden brown and once that's been
accomplished we can transfer those onto
the same plate and we will simply let
those two ingredients cool while we move
on to the third maybe most important
ingredient our red peppers and there's
basically two ways we can go here
we can go ahead and roast fresh bell
peppers which is always a nice option
but does take more work and possibly is
more expensive than actually using the
jarred peppers which would be your
second option and I'm going to review
those two choices a little bit on the
block but bottom line both fresh and
jarred will work beautifully in this
however if you do decide to rock the
bells some very important advice when we
blacken these peppers to remove the skin
whether we're doing it on an open burner
like this or under a broiler or on the
grill we need to do much more than just
blacken the skin okay the skins gonna
turn black relatively fast but that
doesn't mean we take them off we want to
leave these on until they soften and the
flesh of the pepper actually gets
roasted through so we're not going to
pull them off just because they're black
we're gonna pull them off because
they're black and soft which is exactly
the state these were in when I transfer
them into this bowl but wait there's
more
to hedge our bets what we'll do is wrap
this tightly in plastic and let that sit
on the counter for about 15 or 20
minutes to allow time for those peppers
to continue to steam in that smoky
goodness plus as you'll see after about
20 minutes when we unwrap this they are
going to be extremely easy to peel and
of course besides removing the skin we
will also cut out the seed pod and any
membranes which I will not be showing
cuz you know how to do that so I went
ahead and remove the skin as well as the
seeds and membranes and by the way so
you're not confused with the amounts
here I'm not gonna use all these we're
only gonna need about a cup roughly
chopped but hey if you're gonna roast
peppers do some extra I mean come on
those grilled Italian sausages are not
gonna accessorize themselves but anyway
once our crumbs and nuts are toasted and
our peppers are roasted we'll go ahead
and toss that into our food processor
and then proceed to add the following
ingredients so to this we're also going
to add some crushed garlic as well as
some freshly squeezed lemon juice and
then a little bit of the one-and-only
exotic ingredient here some pomegranate
molasses also known as pomegranate
concentrate and yes of course I'm the
blog I'll tell you what to do if you
can't find that although you can and
then we'll go ahead and season this up
with some kosher salt
as well as a nice spoon of paprika and
be careful that's regular paprika the
smoked paprika might be too strong for
this and it will also do a little bit of
ground cumin as well as a few shakes of
cayenne pepper and then speaking of
pepper if you can find it we also want
to add one spoon of Aleppo pepper flakes
which are not only gorgeous but there's
no seeds which is kind of nice and then
we'll finish this up with a few
tablespoons of olive oil and other than
maybe adjusting with some salt later
that is pretty much gonna be it we'll go
ahead and take that over and process it
by pulsing on and off and as usual I'm
not going to show it but you want to
stop this a few times during the process
and kind of scrape down the sides with a

while the texture of this really will
vary depending on who's making it I
personally tend to side with team smooth
and do like to process this fairly fine
which you're not gonna get a good look
at until I pull this off and transfer it

I feel free to do yours a little less or
a little more you are after all the
yo-yo ma of your move hamurana so
whatever texture strikes the right chord

I'm gonna serve this cold I'm not going
to adjust the seasonings yet I'm gonna

then pop that in the fridge for about an

money shots and then once successfully
chilled we'll go ahead and unwrap it and
give it a taste for seasoning and
believe it or not mine was spot-on but
don't be surprised if yours is gonna

we're happy with how that's tasty we'll

what we'll do once that transfer didn't
is take a spoon or spatula and create
what I call the garnish gully right this
is a little trick I picked up from
Middle Eastern restaurants I frequents
and what that's going to do is create a
little bit of visual interest on the
surface which of course is just a
euphemism for make the texture look
slightly less off-putting and then into
our garnish skully we'll finish up with
some chopped walnuts as well as maybe
some more pepper flakes and possibly a

appears to be pouring from my fingertip
and then we'll finish up a little bit of
freshly chopped to tell you parsley and
